metadata.titleEn: Organic contamination and ancient DNA extraction of six hanging coffin human remains
metadata.description: DNA was extracted from teeth or phalanx. Firstly, we conducted 2 hours UVirradiation on the samples, and removed a layer of surface using a sterile dentistry trill, then again irradiated with 1 hour UV-light on the samples. We drilled out ~80 mg of bone powder for every sample with the sterile dentistry trill,  and only do 2 samples at one time (include following procedures until performing sequencing; samples from different archaeological sites were never handled together) to avoid potential individual cross-contamination. Using the 80 mg bone powder, we performed DNA extraction following the silica suspension protocol from an early report (Rohland and  Hofreiter 2007), which was modified afterwards (Allentoft, et al. 2015) for customizing recovering of more shorter DNA fragments, that finally resulting a total of 100 μl aliquots for each sample. In brief, the bone powder was digested over night with proteinase K in 0.5M EDTA plus 10% N-Laurylsarcosyl suspension,  then the released DNA was absorbed in solution which includes PB buffer, 5M sodium acetate, 5M sodium chloride and SiO2 suspension, and followed by three times of purification using 80% ethyl alcohol. Finally, after airing, the DNA was eluted with 100 μl EB buffer. Next, to perform preliminary aDNA preservation situation screening,  using 20μl DNA aliquots of each sample, we built the double strand library (DSL) with no Uracil- DNA-Glycosylase (UDG) treatment under a single indexing with commercial kit (cat no: E7370) from New England Biolabs (Ipswich, MA) following the manufacturer’s guidelines, as previously reported (Meyer and Kircher 2010) that includes end prep,  adaptor ligation, purification, PCR amplification and size selection steps. PCRs were conducted in a final volume of 50 μl using AmpliTaq Gold 360 DNA Polymerase (AmpliTaq Gold, Life Technologies Applied Biosystems) which is able to well amplify across uracils, preserve the DNA damage pattern that induced by deamination,  which indicating of authentic aDNA (Krause,  et al. 2010). We performed all the sequencing (also the following captured library sequencing) on the Illumina HiSeq X Ten (PE-150) platform ( https://www.illumina.com.cn/systems/sequencing-platforms/hiseq-x.html ). The calculated appraise indexes of aDNA quality and preservation are shown in Table S1. Lastly,  we rebuilt the DSLs with 3 hours UDG treatment using the remaining DNA extraction aliquots, which could largely remove uracil residues from DNA fragmental end to leave abasic sites, and cuts the DNA at the 5´ and 3´ sides of the abasic sites with enzyme endonuclease VIII (Endo VIII). For these libraries,  we performed the mtDNA capture using myBaits® Mito-Target Capture Kits as previous report (Enk, et al. 2014). Briefly, we used the biotinylated RNA “baits” that are transcribed from the human genomic DNA to perform the capture in solution overnight at 65°C,  then mixed in streptavidin-coated magnetic beads and sequestered the targets with a magnetic stand. The PCRs for both pre-capture and post-capture are performed using KAPA HiFi Hot start Polymerase (KAPA BIOSYSTEMS).

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to extract ancient DNA from bone samples while minimizing contamination risks?
Example.Answer: A data collection method involved extracting DNA from teeth or phalanx by first conducting UV irradiation on the samples, removing a surface layer using a sterile dentistry trill, and drilling out bone powder. This process was specifically designed to minimize contamination by handling only two samples at a time from different archaeological sites separately.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of DNA extraction methods used for ancient human bone samples?
Feature Specification.Answer: UV irradiation, removal of surface layers, drilling of bone powder, modified silica suspension protocol, minimize contamination, preserve short DNA fragments, digestion with proteinase K, purification steps.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of using UV irradiation in the preparation of ancient bone samples for DNA extraction?
Definition.Answer: UV irradiation is used to sterilize and decontaminate the surface of ancient bone samples, helping to reduce the risk of external contamination before DNA extraction. This process ensures that the DNA being analyzed is more likely to be authentic ancient DNA rather than modern contaminants.

Comparison.Question: How do the DNA extraction methods from teeth or phalanx compare to DNA extraction methods from other skeletal remains in terms of contamination prevention and DNA preservation?
Comparison.Answer: The DNA extraction methods from teeth or phalanx involve several steps to prevent contamination and preserve DNA, including UV irradiation, sterile removal of the surface layer, and using a silica suspension protocol for extraction. This can be compared to other skeletal remains where different protocols might be used, potentially affecting the level of contamination prevention and quality of DNA preservation.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors lead to potential cross-contamination during the extraction of ancient DNA from skeletal remains?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Potential cross-contamination during the extraction of ancient DNA from skeletal remains can be attributed to handling multiple samples at the same time, especially if they originate from different archaeological sites. To minimize this risk, the samples were processed two at a time, ensuring that samples from different sites were never handled together.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps involved in extracting ancient DNA from bone samples while minimizing contamination and maximizing DNA recovery?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedural steps for extracting ancient DNA from bone samples include: 1) Conducting UV irradiation on the samples for 2 hours followed by surface layer removal using a sterile dentistry trill, then irradiating again with UV-light for 1 hour. 2) Drilling out approximately 80 mg of bone powder per sample with a sterile dentistry trill, ensuring only two samples are processed concurrently to prevent individual cross-contamination. 3) Performing DNA extraction using a modified silica suspension protocol to recover shorter DNA fragments, resulting in 100 μl aliquots per sample. 4) Digesting the bone powder overnight with proteinase K in a 0.5M EDTA plus 10% N-Laurylsarcosyl suspension, followed by DNA absorption in a solution containing PB buffer, sodium acetate, sodium chloride, and SiO2 suspension, with purification using 80% ethyl alcohol. 5) Eluting the DNA with 100 μl EB buffer and constructing a double strand library (DSL) without UDG treatment for preliminary aDNA screening. 6) Conducting PCR amplification and sequencing using the Illumina HiSeq X Ten platform. 7) Rebuilding DSLs with a 3-hour UDG treatment to remove uracil residues and performing mtDNA capture using myBaits® Mito-Target Capture Kits.
